trans-unit.source: a project from the SLUB Dresden and the University of Rostock
Welcome to the Virtual Map Forum 2.0
New to the Virtual Map Forum 2.0?
Are you sure you want to logout
Please inform us about your ideas, problems or suggestions.
Please insert your contact message in this text field.
Die SLUB ist eine Anstalt öffentlichen Rechts.

Die SLUB ist die Staatsbibliothek des Freistaates Sachsen und zugleich die Universitätsbibliothek der Technischen Universität Dresden. Sie wird durch den Generaldirektor, Herrn Prof. Dr. Thomas Bürger, gesetzlich vertreten.
Der Staatsminister für Wissenschaft und Kunst übt die Dienst- und Fachaufsicht über die Anstalt aus.

Trotz unserer sorgfältigen Bemühungen können wir keine Gewähr für die Richtigkeit, Vollständigkeit und Aktualität unserer Webseiten geben. Weiter übernehmen wir keine Haftung für die Inhalte externer Links. Für den Inhalt der verlinkten Seiten sind ausschließlich deren Betreiber verantwortlich. Die SLUB behält es sich vor, Teile des Internetangebotes oder das gesamte Angebot ohne gesonderte Ankündigung zu ändern, zu ergänzen, zu löschen oder die Veröffentlichung zeitweise oder endgültig einzustellen.
Das Layout der Homepage, die verwendeten Grafiken sowie die sonstigen Inhalte sind urheberrechtlich geschützt.

The Virtual Map Forum 2.0 offers a lot of tools and content. General topics as the FAQ, the Contact details, the Project or the Masthead / Impressum can be accessed through the buttons in the footer or the button above the map search on the left side.

If you click either on the German or the English flag you can change the language of the Virtual Map Forum 2.0. You can log in or register by clicking on the login button. With the button in the right upper corner you can toggle in the full-screen-mode.
Right now you can find and displayed more than 4.700 georeferenced maps in the portal of the Virtual Map Forum 2.0.

Using the navigation directly on the map or through the input of a place name respectively a map sheet number in the search field of the spatiotemporal search module (left part / main page) you can choose the relevant spatial area. The spatiotemporal search module also displays the relevant search results for your spatiotemporally selected criteria. Through using the time slider you can also adjust the relevant time period for your search results.

If you type in the input box a place name the application offers you a select list of possible place names. By choosing a place name from this list with your mouse or the keyboard the map jumps right to this place. You can alternatively type in the map sheet number (like 49_48) and this will guide you to the right place as well.

With the help of the time bar you can adjust the period of your search time. Right now the portal offers you maps between the years 1868 and 1945. Therefore these years represent the maximum range of time. The adjusting of the search period affects the listed results in the search list.

The search list displays all available maps for the appropriate spatial segment and search time. The header of the search list shows the number of search hits. Beneath, you can sort the results by pressing the buttons Title or Time. If you click on a search result, the appropriate historical map will be displayed on the main map and automatically be transferred to the "My Maps" map container.

Every single search result will be displayed with its lemma, time stamp (dating) and its scale. Furthermore there will be given a Thumbnail image of the relevant map. If you move your mouse over a search result, the spatial expansion of the map will be represented in a polygon on the main map.
The picture left hand side shows the different navigation tools which can be used on the maps.
By pressing the + or the - you can zoom into or out of the map (you can also use the mouse wheel)

The Magnifier button activates a map magnifier. If you move it over a historical map it will show the recent OpenStreetMap for this part. Press y and the area for the magnifier gets bigger. Press x and the area gets smaller.
Press and hold the Shift key and press and move the mouse at the same time you rotate the map. Press the Needle button the map will be "northed" again.
The last button allows you to create a link of the current map view and to share it with other users.

If you choose a map in the spatiotemporal search module it will be added automatically to the main map and to the map management container. In this map management container you can change the transparency of maps, activate and deactivate maps, you can add related maps, delete any map from your own selection and it is possible to change the order of the presentation of the maps on the main map.

If you click with your mouse on the bar and slide it up- or downwards you can change the transparency of the chosen map. This will help you to see the changing in the landscapes and to check the georeferencing of your map.
By clicking with your mouse on the green square you can either activate or deactivate the corresponding map sheet.

To add a map sheet choose the one you would like to work on from the listed map sheets beneath the spatiotemporal search module by just clicking on it with your mouse or by using the keyboard. The map sheet will automatically be transferred to the "My Maps" map container.
To delete a map sheet just press the "x" button beneath the activate / deactivate tool.

To reorder maps use your mouse cursor. Click on the thumbnail version of one map sheets in your "My Maps" map container and press and hold it. Then you can easily move it up- or downwards in the container to change the order of the map sheets.

If you want to have a map at the very top you can either use the drag- and-drop method or you can just click on the symbol above the activate / deactivate switch. So the map you just clicked on will automatically be moved to the top of the list.

If you selected one map from the plane survey sheet search list by clicking on it and then click on the corresponding square in the main map you will get further information about the map sheet. You will also be given a picture of the original map sheet.

And you can receive even more information by clicking on one of the two boxes shown left. "Gehe zu Fotothek" leads you to the photographic library which provides the map sheet and "Zeige Metadatensatz" gives you more meta data.
